The latter are equated with the Cretan Hippeis,  and the Synepheboi with the Cretan naQouyra & évreç.  This is followed by a discussion of the relation of the Cretan Andreia to the Spartan Syssitia and in turn to the Hetaireiai,  and by an acute study of the Testament of Epikteta as illustrating the organisation of an Andreion,  »a closely related group of adult male kindred in the male line« in another Dorian state,  usually believed to be Thera. 
Chapter VII »The Cult and Festival of Orthia«,  though described as »in the nature of a digression «,  is intended to illustrate not only the ty from ancient to Roman Sparta,  but also that from the Mycenaean Age to early Dorian times.  Thus Nilsson's suggesti'on that the Peloponnesian Artemis was a direct survival from the Cretan »goddess of wild lifet is accepted and developed,  with special emphasis on the costume of the goddess Orthia as represented on the lead figurines,  which is interpreted as »a very full bell - shaped skirt with many flounces worn over an under - dress with an all - over diagonal pattern It is also suggested that the tive cult - image was dressed in detachable clothes ( the ( poQoç offered in Alcman's Partheneion representing the annual change of robe ),  and the pattern of the under - dress may really represent a wicker frame - work for the bell - shaped skirt,  giving rise to the epithet Lygodesma, 
Other parallels quoted with the Cretan noxvia & r\q ( bv may be passed over.  The »close connection of both goddesses with navigation« is claimed largely on the comparison of the famous Spartan ivory plaque representing a ship with the gold ring from Candia ( Pl.  5,  [ b,  c ] ),  each of which is regarded as a scene of safe arrival,  not of departure ; but we may well ask whether the artist of the ivory plaque would have represented a ship as arriving stern first,  with the steersman looking out to sea?  And is it quite certain that the female figure on the quay is the goddess herself? 
The title Orthia is explained as meaning the goddess of the steep mountain,  the name having nothing to do with the upright form of the cult image ( we may agree that »uprightness« is not a distinctive feature among primitive cult images,  and that the mountain - association is far from impossible,  but our difficulties do not end here ).  If the cult was of Minoan origin and survived into Dorian times,  why are there no structural remains or pre - Hellenic votives ( apart from a few Mycenaean gems )?
